Award.AwardTitle: AF: Small: RUI: Geometric Graphs for Directional Communication

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project studies fundamental combinatorial, geometric, and graph-theoretical problems related to the design of wireless networks with directional antennas. The goal is to maximize communication robustness and security while minimizing power consumption and interference. The technical focus is on determining theoretical and algorithmic relationships between antenna parameters (orientation, range, angle), and the structure of the induced communication graph (such as connectivity, fault tolerance, and spanning ratio).

This study will generate fresh approaches to geometric algorithms tuned to directional antennas, which must necessarily push beyond known geometric techniques. Building a bridge between theoretical computer science and the burgeoning area of communication networks is a key for scientific advancement, with a potential significant economical impact on the design of wireless communication networks.

This project will involve collaborations with under-represented students, who will be fully engaged in designing and testing the necessary simulation software, and will explore conjectures both theoretically and through simulations. This will provide a path for talented under-represented students to enter the world of scientific research, who will then serve as role models for the entire body of computer scientists. Theoretical results will be disseminated broadly in conference publications and journal papers. Simulation software will be made available to researchers and teachers worldwide.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This research investigated fundamental combinatorial geometric problems related to communication issues in wireless ad-hoc and sensor networks equipped with directional antennas. Specifically, we explored geometric relationships between antenna parameters, such as orientation, aperture and transmission range, and properties of the induced communication graph, such as connectivity, spanning ratio, power consumption and interference. Understanding such relationships is crucial to fully exploit key features of directional antennas, such as achieving longer communication links with narrower beams. The use of narrow beams allows energy saving for a given communication range, or extends the range for a given transmission power level. It also reduces the chance for interference and eaves-dropping. These characteristics promise a significant long-term economic potential for directional communication networks. 


The main contributions of this research are fresh approaches for analyzing unknown properties of existing communication graphs, and for constructing new efficient communication spanners. Our constructions are sensitive to the fact that resources, such as memory and battery power, are often limited, and that wireless nodes can exhibit a high degree of mobility. Because of this, our constructions are mainly localized, meaning that each wireless node determines its communication neighbors based on information obtained from a small neighborhood. This way, changes in one part of the communication graph are insulated from the rest of the graph, and the communication network can quickly self-repair in the presence of faults. 


This award provided support in the form of mentorship and research assistantship to four Master's students and one undergraduate student. Three of these students have co-authored papers resulted from this research, and have presented their results at international conferences; the other two students have contributed to the development of interactive software for simulating the behavior and performance of some classes of wireless spanners. This software is now freely available on the Wolfram Demonstration Project website.
